results.title: Italian government debt slips to €2.13tn
results.content:
Italy's debts dipped slightly to €2.13tn in September despite the shrinking economy weighing on tax revenues and spurring the government to shelve any fiscal cut-backs to avoid worsening the recession.

The Italian government's debt burden is one of the highest in the world – the International Monetary Fund projects it will hit 136 per cent of GDP this year – and spends over 5 per cent of GDP just on interest payments.

The decline in the government's gross debts in September is a welcome reminder that the trajectory can be twisted downward, but with the economy shrinking another 0.1 per cent in the third quarter, Matteo Renzi's administration faces a huge challenge in reducing the debts meaningfully.

An economic advisor to Mr Renzi has promised "an atomic bomb" of tax cuts to help the sclerotic economy grow, but the IMF expects Italy's debt-to-GDP ratio will still be at 130 per cent in 2017 (and has continually erred on the side of optimism in recent years).
results.abstract: Italy's debts dipped slightly to €2.13tn in September despite the shrinking economy weighing on tax revenues and spurring the government to shelve any fiscal cut-backs to avoid worsening the recession.

results.title: Housing leads UK construction rise in September
results.content:
The UK's construction industry recovered in September, after August's unexpected plunge in output, although a month-on-month rise of 1.8 per cent in volumes was less than expected.

Official figures from the Office for National Statistics show a rise of 3.5 per cent on a year ago, compared to a 0.3 per cent contraction in August and expectations of a 3.9 per cent rise from economists polled by Reuters.

There was a month-on-month fall of 3.9 per cent in August and economists had expected this to reverse to a 4.0 per cent rise in September, so 1.8 per cent ranks as a disappointment.

Six weeks ago, the Markit/CIPS Construction Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) gave a reading of 64.2 for September, up from 64.0 in August and representing an eight-month high. Ten days ago, it disappointed with an October reading of 61.4.

Demand for new housing has been a driver of the UK's economic recovery and that continued in September, however. The ONS said:

Upward pressure on the quarter and on the month came from new housing which was at its highest monthly level since the series began in 2010. While there was strength in private new housing during this period, public new housing was at its highest monthly level since the series began in 2010, and its quarterly level was the highest since the series began in 1997.

results.title: HK-China Stock Connect tax hitch resolved
results.content:
One of the major potential pitfalls of a highly anticipated scheme to allow Hong Kong and Shanghai investors to buy stocks in each other's markets has been removed, according to a statement by China's finance ministry.

In a notice, the ministry said it would "temporarily" waive a capital gains tax for foreigners buying Chinese stocks under the scheme, called Stock Connect, which is due to start on November 17. It did not specify how long the waiver would last.

That removes a major drawback for foreign investors. Many Chinese companies' shares are already listed in Hong Kong, and the separately governed territory does not apply capital gains tax on share trading. So a requirement for foreign investors to pay China's ten per cent CGT on profits on Shanghai 'A' shares may have kept many trading exclusively in Hong Kong's 'H' Share market.

Separately, Chinese investors buying Hong Kong shares under the scheme, which has been hailed as a major step in opening China's mostly closed off markets, will be exempted from income tax on these purchases for three years.

The finance ministry said:

Considering that the Shanghai-HK stock connect is in a trial stage, in order to attract mainland individual investors to invest in Hong Kong and promote the spread of the trial program, the agencies are offering this tax advantage.
results.abstract: One of the major potential pitfalls of a highly anticipated scheme to allow Hong Kong and Shanghai investors to buy stocks in each other's markets has been removed, according to a statement by China's finance ministry.

results.title: Italy's economy falls back into recession in Q3
results.content:
Italy's economy shrank 0.1 per cent in the third quarter, falling back into recession, in yet another disappointing set of figures that underline the urgency facing prime minister Matteo Renzi in implementing reforms.

While the quarter-on-quarter contraction was in line with economists' forecasts, it means that Italy's economy has recorded either zero or negative growth in every quarter since the June-September period of 2011.

This lack of growth makes it difficult for Italy to bring down its unemployment rate, which is higher than 12 per cent, making it increasingly reliant on exports as a source of growth at a time when the broader eurozone is stagnating, growth in China is slowing and Russian sanctions are curtailing shipments there.

The news follows announcements earlier this morning showing that France's economy grew 0.3 per cent in the third quarter and Germany's expanded 0.1 per cent. The eurozone's announcement is expected at 10am London time.
results.abstract: Italy's economy shrank 0.1 per cent in the third quarter, falling back into recession, in yet another disappointing set of figures that underline the urgency facing prime minister Matteo Renzi in implementing reforms.

results.title: IEA says oil price could fall further in 2015
results.content:
A return to previous oil price highs may not be on the horizon, says the International Energy Agency, hailing a new era in crude markets.

"Supply and demand balances suggest that the price rout has yet to run its course," said the wealthy nation's energy watchdog in its closely watched monthly oil report.

"Barring any new supply disruption, downward price pressures could build further in the first half of 2015."

"It is increasingly clear that we have begun a new chapter in the history of the oil markets," it added.

Neil Hume, Commodities Editor, reports the price of Brent, the international oil benchmark, has plunged by 30 per cent to $77.92 since mid-June, despite key oil producing regions — such as Libya and Iraq — being stuck in the throes of bloody conflict.

Weaker than expected demand has coincided with relentless growth in US production and a surplus of oil in the Atlantic Basin, as well as the North Sea. A stronger dollar has also helped to push the price of Brent lower.
results.abstract: A return to previous oil price highs may not be on the horizon, says the International Energy Agency, hailing a new era in crude markets.

results.title: Europe edges higher on recession relief
results.content:
Europe's markets have edged higher at the open on Friday, after initial GDP figures showed its largest economy narrowly avoided slipping back into recession in the third quarter.

Germany grew 0.1 per cent as expected, compared to a 0.1 per cent contraction in the second quarter - revised upwards from -0.2 per cent. There was good news from France as well - flash GDP figures showed 0.3 per cent growth - higher than expectations of 0.1 per cent and a flat second quarter.

Mike van Dulken, Head of Research at Accendo Markets, commented:

In focus today after major contributors France and Germany's positive start, will be the Eurozone GDP print [at 10am London time] which could be better than expected, although weakness elsewhere (Italy etc) could still hamper progress. With growth one thing and prices another, all eyes [will be] on the accompanying inflation data and whether it continues to flirt with deflation.

On the main indices:

  • The FTSE Eurofirst 300 is up 0.03 per cent or 0.4 points at 1,347 points.

  • The FTSE 100 in London is flat at 6,632.

  • The Xetra Dax in Frankfurt is up 0.3 per cent or 24 points at 9,273.

  • The CAC 40 in Paris is up 0.2 per cent or 8 points at 4,196.

Bouygues is top of the FTSE Eurofirst 300 - up 5 per cent at €28.43 - after the telecoms group raised forecasts for 2014 turnover.

It's followed by Airbus - 3 per cent higher at €49.16 - after the European aerospace group handsomely beat analysts' expectations of its preferred profit measure for the third quarter.

Julius Baer is at the bottom of the index - down 4.4 per cent at SFr42.02 in Zurich, with the Swiss bank failing to elaborate on negotiations over a settlement of the tax-evasion investigation by the US.

In London, Aggreko is top of the FTSE 100 - up 4 per cent at £16.04 - after the equipment hire company reaffirmed underlying profit guidance for the year.

Premier Farnell is bottom of the FTSE 250 - down 8 per cent at 165.5p - after it warned softer trading for the electronics distributor in Asia and Europe would hit margins.
results.abstract: Europe's markets have edged higher at the open on Friday, after initial GDP figures showed its largest economy narrowly avoided slipping back into recession in the third quarter.

results.title: Chinese lending drops amid housing downturn
results.content:
China's banks and shadow lenders extended less credit than analysts had expected in October, as the leveraged economy weakened and a multi-year housing boom faded.

Aggregate financing, the broad measure of new credit in the financial system, expanded by Rmb663bn.

Analysts had expected a higher figure of Rmb887.5bn, which itself would have been relatively modest.

Of the newly created credit, the vast majority - Rmb548.3bn - came from formal bank lending.

This signals that the nation's shadow banks, including the trust companies funded by retail investors that lend money at high interest rates to real estate developers, are continuing to shy away from risk.

China's economy grew at 7.3 per cent in the third quarter, its slowest expansion since 2009.

After years of investment-led growth fuelled by easy credit, a property boom has also ended. New home prices fell in 69 of 70 Chinese cities in September, according to China's National Bureau of Statistics.

More recent data for October showed that factory production and retail sales were growing at a slower pace than analysts had forecast, which analysts also attributed to the downturn in the housing market.

Beijing's financial regulators may have also played a part in the credit slowdown, as they continued to crack down on riskier forms of off balance sheet lending that had been pumping up the property sector.

Julian Evans-Pritchard of London consultancy Capital Economics wrote:

The October credit data just published support our view that, despite recent liquidity injections, the People's Bank (PBOC) is seeking to keep credit growth on a downward trajectory.

In particular, tougher regulation of off-balance sheet lending appears to have further weighed on the issuance of bankers acceptance bills and trust loans which continued to see net repayments last month.
results.abstract: China's banks and shadow lenders extended less credit than analysts had expected in October, as the leveraged economy weakened and a multi-year housing boom faded.

results.title: Nokia raises margin targets for 2015
results.content:
Nokia's life after mobile phones is looking ever rosier, with the Finnish telecoms equipment provider raising its forecasts for operating margins in the coming year.

At its Capital Markets Day event in London, Nokia said it now had a target for Nokia Networks' long-term operating margin range to be 8 per cent to 11 per cent. - compared to its previous target of 5 to 10 per cent.

For the 2015 full year, it expects Nokia Networks to meet the new long-term target of 8 to 11 per cent.

It also expects net sales to grow slightly faster than the market over the long-term.

On spending plans, Nokia expects capex to be around €200m in 2015.

It's Nokia's first investor day since it sold its mobile phone business to Microsoft to focus on telecoms network, navigation services and its patent portfolio. Nokia President and CEO, Rajeev Suri, commented:

This meeting with investors comes on the heels of a quarter where we demonstrated growth across our three businesses. It showed the potential of this company when it starts to execute well.

Read Daniel Thomas, Telecoms Correspondent, on Nokia's revival through its networks business.
results.abstract: Nokia's life after mobile phones is looking ever rosier, with the Finnish telecoms equipment provider raising its forecasts for operating margins in the coming year.

results.title: Stamp dealer Stanley Gibbons posts bumper profits
results.content:
Stanley Gibbons has reported a bumper set of half-year numbers, as the stamp and coin dealer enjoyed returns from the sale of a number of high-value collections.

The British company said that its net income soared by 537 per cent to £3.2m in the half year to July. Its revenues grew to £27.1m from £17.2m, although excluding recent acquisitions turnover was flat.

Its preferred earnings measure of like-for-like trading profits rose 93 per cent to £3.7m.

Chairman Martin Bralsford said:

The growth in like-for-like profits of 93% in the period was primarily the result of the initial crystallisation of returns from some recent exceptional purchases of major high quality collections.

The group's bottom line is heavily influenced by whether or not it makes high value sales. In its philately division, its largest client spent £3m, the company said.

Stanley Gibbons is also banking on its good luck streak continuing as it moves philately and coin collecting into the digital age. It has developed a new online marketplace for collectibles, a service it has soft-launched with plans to add more features for a formal launch early next year.
results.abstract: Stanley Gibbons has reported a bumper set of half-year numbers, as the stamp and coin dealer enjoyed returns from the sale of a number of high-value collections.

results.title: IMI in €153m valve deal as FX hits revenues
results.content:
IMI is bolting on a valve company, with the UK engineering firm buying Germany's Bopp & Reuther at an enterprise value of €152.6m (£120m).

The FTSE 100 company says B&R will become part of its critical engineering division as it is closely aligned with its existing control valve business.

Efficiencies worth around €9m are expected from the combination by the end of 2017.

Mark Selway, chief executive of IMI, said:

It gives us critical mass in the power sector particularly in the faster growing geographies of China and India. It also expands our product portfolio, enabling us to offer customers complete valve packages and Bopp & Reuther's existing installed base gives us access to a bigger aftermarket opportunity.

The news came with a trading update that showed adjusted organic earnings rose 1 per cent year on year in the four months to the end of October and are up 2 per cent year-to-date. However, on a reported basis, revenues were down 6 per cent for the four months "reflecting the ongoing adverse impact of exchange rate movements".

The outlook for the year is still broadly in line with current market expectations, it said, despite market conditions being more difficult than anticipated, particularly in Germany.

The company said in a statement:

In the second half of the year we expect to deliver modest organic revenue growth and, as outlined in the Interim Results, our investments for growth are expected to result in margins being slightly lower compared to the same period last year.
results.abstract: IMI is bolting on a valve company, with the UK engineering firm buying Germany's Bopp & Reuther at an enterprise value of €152.6m (£120m).
